review_title: Good opportunities to work with a professor
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Richardson, TX
pros: You can learn research working with great professors
cons: Not much money for 5 years

job_title: Lab Manager and Research Technician Two in Dallas, TX
pros: Utsw has a building right across the street where a lot of employees live.
cons: Most live across the street because they are called in at 11pm 2am 6am … worked over 90 hours a week without compensation for more than 35. Very toxic environment. Reported harassment and HR retaliated. Toxic mold infestation through tall the labs and the cancer center. Was in the hospital twice because of the mold. They took away my project have me secretary work instead isolates me by leaving me in the moldy lab while everyone else was out into a clean lab. Accessed my medical records and shared with other employees. A multitude of illegal and unethical activity.

pros:
health benefits
retirement plan
other insurance products (life/disability)
cons:
Administrative hierarchy
little control over schedule

pros: great leadership and great staff community
cons: pay is very low for the work we do

review_title: It's annoying to have to do this just to get to the information
job_title: Full Time Faculty in McAllen, TX
pros: Great colleagues to work with
cons: Hot weather all the time

review_title: Lots to like, but not perfect
pros:
Excellent pay and benefits
The longer you stay, the more you get paid and more vacation you accumulate
cons: Lots of corporate disconnect, even for a government entity

pros: The company has great benefits
cons: The company does not promote people of color

pros: Part time teaching assistantship helps with tuition
cons: need to multitask between study and work.

pros: laid-back work flow, easy to juggle with classes
cons: Supervisor is very difficult to contact, almost never responds to calls or emails.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Arlington, TX
pros: Learn new things and be able to apply them on real world data
cons: Not getting paid for the position

review_title: Personal job satisfaction possible inspite of a bloated and ineffective administration.
pros:
1.  For non-academic staff, there is an effort to address "Work-Life". 
2.  Several effective methods of communication with employees who have access to computers and the time to read the various e-mails and newsletters.
3.  Satisfaction of making a contribution to medical education and patient care.
cons:
1.  Consistent lack of effective top administrators (President and CFO, but also many Deans).  The selection of the top administrator is a flawed process, because non-qualified large donors on the development board and political appointees from the Board of Regents have undue power in the selection process.

2.  Adminstration values loyalty at all costs and considers any critical analysis as disloyal.  The Presidents have consistently surrounded themselves with "yes-men" and have not consulted with those with expertise in the organization before decisions are made.

3.  Too much of the resources of the Health Science Center has been used for administrative salaries and positions.

For non-academic staff there are several downsides:
1.  Lack job protection for the average employee.  There is a recent history of cutting positions, regardless of how close to retirement, just to save money, but then turning around and nearly doubling the salary of the administrator who was brought in by the Board of Regents.
2.  Work load increase without increased salary - many support staff positions were cut while the work load increased - especially true in non-academic departments.

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker LCSW in Fort Worth, TX
pros: It was good place to work.
cons: Really just completing this so I can get my Glassdoor account activated.

pros: The are a good number of resources available for faculty members.  The students are motivated and some of the top students in the country so the classroom setting is good.  The intellectual environment is strong.  There are top scholars in a variety of fields which allows for the possibility of successful collaboration.  The teaching load is reasonable given the expectations for research and publishing.  Further, there is a concentrated effort to protect junior faculty from the demands of administrative duties.  Finally, Austin is a great city to live in and there is ample opportunities to pursue interests away from work.
cons: The publishing hurdle is high but not unreasonable.  Also there is a fair amount of pressure to be visible and to put in face time on campus.  In addition, because there are such strong faculty, there is also the downside of egos that go along with that.  Sometimes egos get in the way of making decisions that are in the best interests of departments, colleges, and the university as a whole.  In addition, although there are resources, the is an impetus on new faculty to prove themselves worthy of deserving those resources which can complicate the process of tenure and promotion.

job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Austin, TX
pros:
Great managers and co-workers.
Mostly enjoyable work.
Good Benefits (Pension, Insurance)
Good work-life balance
Most work is not extremely urgent, and therefore usually not too stressful.
cons:
The salary increases are very slow.
Staying up to date with software development technologies is slow and difficult.

pros: UTD is a regionally well known university that is becoming more recognized at the national level, and has lots of growth potential in the coming years.  They are spending hundreds of millions of dollars in new development on the campus.  The university administration seems like they are dedicated to raising UTD to tier 1 status.  The campus has a student enrollment of about 15,000, and they are looking to increase that number by 5,000 in the next few years.  In 20 years it will probably be one of the top university's in the State of Texas.  The people are also nice.
cons: Low pay compared to similar jobs in the surrounding area.  The university administration does not seem dedicated to trying to raise the salaries by any significant level, just enough to placate people so they won't leave.  Also, the tuition reimbursement is mediocre.  Most surrounding municipalities have full tuition reimbursement for six hours a semester at UTD, but UTD only provides 6 hours a semester at a discounted rate.  The campus is also hideous, although the administration has been spending money to make the campus more visually appealing.  My advice to anyone looking to apply here is look elsewhere for better compensation and tuition reimbursement.

review_title: Consider your options carefully before accepting a position at UTD.
pros: Benefits (other than salary) are good. Most other employees are good to work with. It is generally relatively easy to get time off when needed.  UTD has an excellent reputation in the academic community. UTD is currently trying to earn Tier 1 status so if you are seeking a research faculty position, this would probably be an ideal time to work at UTD, since the departments with research initiatives are currently receiving the best overall support (not to mention the majority of the funding).
cons: Little or no opportunity for advancement, at least in staff positions. Staff are grossly underpaid. Staff members with 15-30 years of professional experience beyond graduate school are earning the same, or less, than new hires with 1-2 years' experience - and this is true across the board (not isolated to a specific department).  As is true of all work environments, every department has its share of extremes: those who work very hard, go way beyond what is required, and put in extra effort and long hours; those on the opposite end who do little or none of their assigned work and are continually allowed to slack off; and many people in-between. The management in many departments suffers from the Peter Principle.

review_title: Great graduate school admin staff, but choose advisors wisely
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: The administrative staff members of the graduate school are for the most part friendly, helpful, and know a number of the students personally. The facilities of the UT Medical School are either brand new or really, really, old depending on where your lab is, but overall adequate. There are also many opportunities for collaboration within the Texas Medical Center institutions, which is quite helpful since so many projects are interdisciplinary. Houston is a very affordable city to live in, which works out nicely with a graduate student's budget.
cons: Graduate students are considered part-time employees, so do not receive the usual employee benefits (401(K), vacation days) provided by the institution. I have no problems with the graduate school itself, though it doesn't seem to have a training program for new advisors. I think this is a crucial mistake because professors take on students for the first time without any idea what to expect other than their own experience as grad students. Suggestions to the grad school have not resulted in any change.

review_title: if you are a work-study, make sure you find a good department to work for.
pros: there's no best reasons to work for UT, as a work-study i would say you got a lot of training and help on your position. but then the same time they just wanted you to do a good job so i guess it evens out. also for my job i didn't have a lot responsibility so i had time to work on my homework or read text books when not busy. any i guess you can also get free coffee, free printing, and get to drive the campus car around and park anywhere you want.  enough said, choose a good department or you are screwed.
cons: for cons, i really don't know where to begin. first of all, my boss, or supervisor always had a bad mood. i would say it had a lot to do with how old this person is or just his/her job in general. this person is really appreciative sometimes but that's only because you do things for her/him and she/he 's happy because she/he didn't have to work on those projects. also if you miss work even though you let them know ahead of time,  they would still not like it very much. i would say UT is very liberal so much of the office people there don't quite care about you that much. when I was leaving they didn't even care.

pros: Very flexible work schedules; can work around your class time. Students are ready and willing to learn.
cons: Need to retake a math assessment per semester. But it is to ensure that tutors are on top of their game

pros: Lots of cutting edge research in my department. Machine learning and signal processing are big topics of interest.
cons: Courses may be lacking in some areas. Professors are helpful enough.

review_title: Great benefits, especially if you're patient.
pros: This is a state agency so we have great insurance benefits. There's a great wellness program that is growing and getting stronger. You can actually retire with an annuity and insurance. This organization is full of really smart, hard-working people. The size of the organization allows for huge potential to affect change. In some departments telecommuting is allowed. The new chancellor is very interested in collaboration and is working hard to facilitate system-wide communication. Overall, the people really do care about each other. Most people do not work over time.
cons: As a very established public employer, there are some antiquated systems and processes. There is less vacation than you might think for government work, and you can't take any time off until you've been employed at least 6 months. Building a career here can be difficult unless you play a really long game and wait for people to retire. There is no succession planning or career path because many people are content to hang out and wait for retirement. Pay can be on the lower side.

review_title: University of Texas is an ever changing and developing university.
job_title: Research Scientist Associate in Austin, TX
pros: The atmosphere on campus is quite varied.  The restaurants on and around campus include many ethnic varieties.  The arts and music the campus attracts is eclectic and the surrounding areas provide amazing scenic drives and day trips.  Support help are extremely helpful and perform a wonderful job.  Although the campus is somewhat spread out among certain offices, the people in the offices are extremely courteous and provide excellent service.  Being in the state capital, the university provides close proximity to government offices and funding sources not readily available at other schools.  If you are a sports fan, it is a great university with top notch teams.
cons: During the school year the campus is overrun with students making it hard to park or get anywhere.  The summers in Texas are brutally hot and can be humid.  Being in a downtown location makes the traffic getting to and from the University of Texas a mess.  The school is geared towards athletics especially during football season with many academic sources pushed aside such as research labs in Belmont Hall to appease the sports teams and fans.  Construction has become common place further disrupting the campus.  The campus is not as picturesque as other well known schools as the architecture is rather repetitive and drab.

job_title: Systems Software Specialist in Richardson, TX
pros: Family oriented, easy to commute to work.
cons: Covid-19 has hit the schools and universities hard

pros:
-Diverse
-Growing
-Entrepreneurial Exposure
-Good faculty
-Plenty of reources
cons:
-Hiring is not active
-Majority international students

pros: Great place to study Education, Engineering, Nursing, etc.
cons: No cons are known about this great university.

review_title: Good to for for, but some compromises are necessary.
pros:
Benefits and a university environment. Working at a university feels like you never left school, but you don't have to go to class anymore. At the same time the benefits are great. Health insurance is great, the teacher retirement system (granted to all staff) is great, discounts for university staff, staff educational benefit (pays for 3 credit hours per semester of tuition and fees), and many others depending on the department.

Vacation and time off is very plentiful, and it's extremely rare to work extra hours outside of the weekly 40.
cons:
Parking! The UT parking nazis are horrible! No space available. When you pay for a parking permit, you might as well throw it away. I wind up parking somewhere in the streets nearby everyday and walk 10-15 minutes to my office.

Most UT departments allow for personal development classes, but usually it's hard to convince a manager to pay for a widely-known certification. Since UT is fairly big, many departments award their own certifications, but they are useless outside of the University.

The salaries are very much lower than in private companies outside of the University.

review_title: IC2 is a For Profit group, Poor Decision makers in real business
pros: Great global opportunities to work with new innovations
cons:
Decision makers have no knowledge of real world innovation and how real world works. Lead Professors only academic and live to keep their jobs, not to help getting innovations on market. No knowledge of financial costs or real world expenses. They also take advantage of emerging market governments contracting with them to aid commercialization, when only teaching them academia outside of classroom giving them opportunities to travel all over the world at other country's expense but never getting products on market. They overkill analysis, as they get paid for paper work. So country is charged thousands for analysis, when 5 min of common sense for free, was all that was necessary.  They also use students (for cheap student pricing) instead of experienced graduates of their own program who could really help companies, because they want to keep money for their own needs more than help emerging country. 

POOR LEADERSHIP.  POOR MISSION AND GOALS.   TALKING THE TALK BUT CAN"T AND DON"T WANT TO WALK THE MILE TO DO IT.

review_title: Expect a solid, state job with mediocre, state pay
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Austin, TX
pros: You can come to work in a very solid, stable job.  The environment is diverse to allow for you to take in arts/humanities, sports, and the like.  Management usually is flexible to allow you to bounce early if needed, work your lunch at the gym, etc.  The compulsory TRS annuity is really good if you get in early and get out early.
cons: Pay stinks compared to other IT opportunities in the area.  Also this place has a tendency to breed 'state employees', which have a hard-headed, bureaucratic mentality.  Plus its _so_ stable, that its hard to can problem employees who impede progress or business.

review_title: Not worth it because of terrible management.
pros: It is a great place to make new friends. Because all of the part time employees are students, it's an easy way to meet new people that you wouldn't otherwise.
cons: At least at Gregory gym, the management is terrible. Those who are responsible for the student staff are very incompetent, despite their years of experience. Unintelligent decisions leave student workers baffled and often don't even slightly consider worker moral. Even though RecSports operates through the work of students it functions like a corporation who doesn't care at all about it's employees.

review_title: Management that cares but the institution doesn't believe in raises
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: University of Texas at Austin is, generally speaking, a really good company to work for. The management, at least in my department, seem to genuinely care about their people. UT has an excellent comp time policy and they are really focused on the work/life balanced, possibly unrivaled. The paid time off is reasonable although I've had better. Scheduling vacation is generally pretty easy unless you are indispensable (a pro and a con, depending on your situation). Work is often interesting and challenging. There is room for promotion and growth for most, especially more junior  developers.
cons: They don't believe in pay raises. Annually you might get a merit bonus. Health, dental, and vision insurance available at a price is OK, coverage is OK not amazing. Vacation scheduling is a bit more strict if you are indispensable. They don't believe in pay raises (I've said this again on purpose). Possibly limited growth (promotion) potential for seasoned developers.

review_title: The politics is worse than you imagine
pros: Great benefits, UT System has lots of (oil) money. It doesn't have to justify its performance  in any way for resources. It's  a privileged bureaucracy in Texas.
cons: Don't do anything cool, because the bureaucrats will go after you if you do. UTSystem is filled with people who play the system. Anyone who challenges the sloth atmosphere is going to get fired. Three months into my employment, my wifi quit working. I later found out that my laptop had been hacked by an IT person who I had challenged and who  was spying on me. I can't prove it, but now that I'm retired I couldn't care less. UT System was the the most shameful place I worked in my 30+ year career in technology.  I don't know if the atmosphere is due to top down politics that just ran off Chancellor McRaven or if it's due to years of bloated bureaucracy. But UT System is a mess and it's no place for a career.

review_title: It used to be a pretty good place to work.
pros: decent benefits, good amount of time off, nice to work in an academic environment and be part of something bigger than yourself.
cons: It is a very silo-ed organization. Seems like the right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing. There are pockets of very inept management and they seem to skate along under the radar and create a hostile and uncomfortable work environment. In certain positions and departments there is not any room for upward movement in positions. They hand pick those people they feel have potential and provide them with a few resources to better themselves but most people are left to fend for themselves.

review_title: The UT Learning Center is provides good on-campus jobs to UT students.
pros: The UT Learning Center is a great place to work as a student at the University of Texas at Austin.  The hours are extremely flexible if you only work on an appointment basis, and the management is very understanding of students' needs -- particularly timeoff requests during midterms and projects.  Tutoring in general is also a great way to hone your academic skills.  You don't truly understand something until you can teach it.  Plus, when you factor in the convenience of being able to schedule your work hours around your classes and being able to work on campus, it's overall a pretty sweet deal.
cons: The wage isn't much, but it pays the bills.  Compensation is probably at or above average for University of Texas campus jobs.

review_title: What start's here changes the world!
pros: The benefits are great and career oppurtunities are wonderful.  The people are nice and very friendly.  There is a great sense of pride to work for the University of Texas.  The University will allow you to work remotely if possible.  Communication is very good because of the overlapping management system that is in place.  It is a great place to build a career because everyone is treated fairly and once you get here it is hard to leave for some reason.
cons: The pay is not great but the compensation package is nice.  Working for a state agency is good but it takes a really long time for any kind of change to happen in our facility.  A six month probationary period is a little long.

review_title: State Employee Syndrome runs rampant with middle management.
pros:
Great benefits
Casual atmosphere
Great location
The job itself is very satisfying
Can be very creative and inspiring
cons:
Horrible pay-far below average, no living wage increases, etc (but the football coach gets $5 mil)
Long hours
Incompetent and absent management
Antiquated processes
Very unorganized throughout the whole organization
It's impossible to get fired so there are a lot of people that barely do their job
Efficiency is not a concern with any department
Everything moves very, very slow
Very challenging to move up because middle management will never leave their positions because they can get away with doing NOTHING 
Too many politics
The faculty are impossible to work with, especially if they have tenure

pros:
it's close to home.  relatively free of upheavals.  there are many opportunities to meet people with very diverse backgrounds and creative ideas.  Some positions are very repetitive in nature, but others offer the opportunity for creativity.  it is possible to move from position to position over the years, and network with other easily accessible departments. 
i believe most people are here either for a very short time, or -ifthey last 2 years- then they are in for the long haul.
cons: no parking whatsoever.  lots of people who are not really motivated in their jobs, and others that are the opposite.  more balance would be nice

review_title: Great benefits and people, but also the usual government stuff
pros:
-Benefits and pay are amazing, even life changing
-Good work life balance when not on call
-Two paid weeks off at holidays
-Lots of autonomy and freedom to get things done
-Fun events for Diwali and Christmas
-Well managed endowment
-Pretty chill environment overall
cons:
-Lots of highly volatile internal politics to navigate (as with any gov't job)
-More managers and team leads than there are employees to be managed
-Leadership and board members have heavy favoritism to Austin staff/UT Austin
-No consistent work from home policy creates inequality
-Not many spots to move up unless you change skill sets or want to manage
-Lots of siloing but also lots of confusion of who does what

pros: I really like the academic environment and the flexibility offered because of it.  I also benefit greatly from the prestige of being at a well respected department.  Austin is a really great city and although the school is very big, I enjoy working with faculty and students in my small research area.
cons: The academic environment (which I also listed as a good thing) and the good old boy structure of tenure/promotion and hiring is extremely frustrating.  Being a postdoc doesn't give you the same kind of collegial feeling as either being a student or regular faculty member.

review_title: Enjoyment Depends on the Team You Work With
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: There's quite a bit of flexibility in the GA position. Depending on who you're working for you don't necessarily have to work in office. Great way to get to know faculty/researchers. Perfect way to build your CV and gain research skills/experiences. If you want to stay in academia there's no better way to get plugged into future opportunities.
cons: Environment can often feel contentious and competitive - this can depend on the department you base out of. Not much support for those wishing to go into a corporate environment post graduation. Opportunities for advancement are limited - mainly a position used as a jumping off point.

review_title: Great place if you can handle an overabundance of directionless management.
pros: There is a large degree of flexibility in both home life and professional development. I enjoy the relaxed environment. You also get good benefits and free bus use.
cons: Limited career development opportunities. Many departments are very heavy on middle management, but most of these positions are superfluous and are not refilled when the person occupying them leaves.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Austin, TX
pros: I've been at the University since 2003 completing a Ph.D in the natural sciences and have found it a great place to begin a career.  Seminars, collaborations, and interactions with other scientists both on and off campus abound.  Stipends and insurance benefits are fair compared to other schools. As with most grad schools, one's satisfaction is largely dependant upon the selection of a graduate adviser or principle investigator.  This is the person who will direct your research for the years to come.  Make sure that you "click".
cons: UT is a huge place.  I would not send someone here for the their undergraduate education.

pros:
Collegiate environment. Great people. Very supportive and at the heart of change. Things have really been improving here adn UT Dallas is certainly headed to become one of the great universities of the next century. 

The university has great diversity and the opportunity to meet people from all over the world. 

The school's traditional focus has been engineering and computer science. Those remain the strongest departments, but others are also growing.
cons: The school is a bit small and, as public schools tend to go, could use more funding. However, both appear to be changing as the university is growing and attracting statewide attention.

review_title: Rec Sports is good for a part time job at UT.
pros:
it was good time, lot of nice people and an extremely diverse work group
got to work on campus while taking classes, very flexible in scheduling.
Pay is good for part time job and you don't really do anything. Also working inside a gym is extremely convenient. It is also easy to get free towel usage for after a work out. The pool is really nice and also another great perk.  I'm pretty sure it's the best campus job here, way better than food services or parking transportation services.
cons: Supervisors are often grad students or inexperienced and will not change after numerous complaints and negative reviews.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Austin, TX
pros: Graduate program is one of the best in prestige, particularly in analytical. Good facilities and often very good funding. With tuition taken care of, you can afford to get a good degree.
cons: Nearly all of the professors are terrible in at least one way. Because of that, you will find a reason to dislike working for them. None of them are terrible in every way, but there are very few good bosses. Great scientists, but lousy bosses. And the ones that are good at both are so cram full of students it is hard to get in.

pros:
Austin-- such a wonderful place to live, this is probably far and away the most convincing reason.
World Class Faculty-- not just a tag line, UT has the funds to attract the very best.
Reasonable compensation scheme.
cons:
Funding Issues-- it seems that they continue to face funding issues and choose to bundle money to attract big name scholars instead of keeping staff.
Benefits are not that great.

pros: Job security, benefits, access to university resources, clearly defined work policies, organized human resources department and employee assistance programs, encouragement and support for continued education
cons: Very low wages for staff, merit increases as well are incredibly low (below the inflation rate of Austin), no bonuses (ever),  difficult to advance career in the creative field, deeply embedded university politics, reporting issues is a bureaucratic process

review_title: Working here has been a great experience that has allowed me to gain many engineering tools.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Working here is a great opportunity to work on premier research that is being conducted in the country.  You will have many opportunities to learn to use tools a techniques that will help you be successful in future jobs.
cons: If you are taking graduate classes it can sometimes be hard to balance classwork and research.  There are not any other cons that I can think of.

pros: It was a wonderful collegiate environment with ample opportunity for research diversity.  The campus provided a wonderful place both to work and live.  There was affordable housing near campus.  It was refreshing to work around so many young people.
cons: At 50,000 plus it was too big for personal training.  Since it is a government institution pay was extremely low compared to the private sector.  The cost of living in Austin has risen sharply in the last fifteen years.  There is very little room for career advancement

pros:
My co-workers are very bright and very nice, and I am very fortunate in my department and management (but some departments are not so nice).  People are not expected to work long hours usually; but the work pace when you are there is pretty intense and there is always too much to do.  Staff get free bus passes to commute to work and can take a free course after a year. Much of the work is interesting.

Some of the administrators and bosses are impressive in their capabilities and dedication and vision.  

Also, it is such a large employer that the varied environments and contacts and people you get to work with can be rewarding and stimulating far beyond working for some small business or something. And of course such a large employer has both good areas to work in and bad ones.
cons:
I do like my job but I have MANY reservations about UT as an employer. Recently there is a push by top management to let go people to suck up money to put toward attracting rock-star faculty and to building a mega-expensive new building. Pay is already very low and this year there are no raises at all and in future years there are likely to be very limited wage hikes.  They have used the recession as an excuse to shaft workers (while their budget actually rose a little). Promotions can be very delayed and in general there is an attitude of contempt of top management for staff and even for regular faculty and their value.  The disloyalty involved in recent layoffs of some excellent people who've spent their lives devoted to the university is appalling; so there is NO REAL JOB SECURITY besides the lousy pay.  Tuition for students keeps rising higher and at the same time they are cutting the value of what students get by increasing class sizes; I don't feel the administration truly cares about education but of course most faculty do.  In many ways it is a crummy place to work, but at the same time if you can find a particular niche that suits you it might be OK; it is OK for me and I do like my job and co-workers and hope to continue working there for a long time; but all the same I don't feel good about a lot of things that are going on or good about UT as an employer in general.  I feel that they count on so many people wanting to work at a university (not something I personally care about) that they are willing to not treat them well and count on their putting up with it.

Pay is very unequal -- most staff are poorly paid but some at the top are far overpaid and get giant raises.  They ask for loyalty from employees and have pretty words but their behavior isn't pretty.  A hiring freeze has resulted in much under-staffing.

review_title: Great opportunity to work with students
pros: Working on a college campus is a great environment coming from the corporate world. There is a lot of support from peers and supervisors and it is refreshing to work with young students. My favorite thing about my job is helping students from their freshman year here and being able to watch them grow through there time here.
cons: Parking is a challenge since this is such a large University. If you live far away or if you are going to be working odd hours, public transportation is way too slow and may not be running at convenient times.

pros: Receive many opportunities to do things you are interested in.  Work with great people, both coworkers and management.  Many resources here.  A lot of flexibility in specific positions.
cons: There have not been major downsides to the positions I've had here.  There are many ways to resolve any challenges and issues.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
It's an academic enviroment that invites you to learn all the time keep you up  to date. 
It's a state job they pay for insurance and employee doesn't have to contribute 
More holidays paid time than private companies
You can use metro rail buses for free with UT id.
cons: Pay day is monthly. Downtown traffic sucks. You have to pay for parking

pros: One of the best reason to work at UT, is the fact that one has the opportunity to be in touch with a very diverse student body.  Very international.
cons: As a large university, it is sometimes difficult to keep abreast with all the changes affecting the organization.

review_title: Great for students who need cash but not as a full time career.
job_title: Cashier Level II  in Austin, TX
pros: I am a student worker so I am a part time worker. The job is very flexible for students and they are willing to work with your schedule. As far as full time cashiers are concerned, they are willing to let cashiers off when needed. It is easy to become a supervisor and work your way up to higher ranks. It is very easy to pick up extra shifts to make extra money and overtime is usually granted if they are desperate for workers. The setting is sort of laid back and on downtimes you can get a little studying done or other side projects.
cons: Unfortunately the downsides of the company are plentiful. As a part time cashier, we receive no benefits and the upper management (those who sit on their asses in the office) believe that we are all replaceable working robots. TRAINING is horrible. There is no set training procedure, so many new employees are just thrown to work and hope for the best. Management really gets mad when you make a mistake and believe that they have adequately trained you when in all actuality you were taught something wrong from someone else who was taught something wrong when they were hired; in essence the cycle continues. And now we have about 25 cashiers who know different methods to doing everything. The full time employees are highly overworked and underpaid and there is always some drama with them. The stories you hear on the job will most likely frighten you to quit or question how some people got hired here, which is another issue within itself. Many people got hired here because of who they know that is already working for the company. That being said, the turnover rate is horrible. I was the only person hired who was interviewed and got the job on my own without any references. It surprises me how many of these people were hired from the interview. Many of the men have horrible work ethic and cant grasp all on the concepts and procedures and are fired after a couple weeks and it takes the supervisors a long time to hire so that leaves us understaffed and many cashiers having to double their work. There is a lot of racial discrimination between supervisors and senior management.

pros: Benefits are agreeable enough, and the opportunities to develop are sometimes worth the disparity in pay. Working for an institution with a distinguished background is also a plus.
cons: Poor vision for the University. There should be a more clearly defined direction for the university to move forward and to advance the state system such that they no longer have to worry about keeping up with the University of California systems

review_title: Excellent leadership, but faculty may have difficulty getting in line.
pros: President David Daniel is a powerful, insightful leader with tangible plans for the future of the University.  The students are delightful, and there is tremendous diversity among the student population.
cons: Professors can treat you as crappy as they want but if they have tenure you just have to take what they dish out.

pros: benefits are great, but be sure to sign up for everything when you start work.  if you need to change your coverage, you can be subjected to "eligible for benefit" paperwork and this might result in you not being approved.  if you start with everything-you are grandfathered in.
cons: upper management mostly incompetent and they lead with complete hands off approach-limiting feedback and information to managers, who are appointed due to acceptance of lower salary and very much a case of "teach to the test"  do not have any original ideas-everything has already been documented for you to follow the rules-do not color outside the box.

job_title: Research Assistant (Electrical Engineering) in Richardson, TX
pros:
•	The university is growing at a fast rate, with support from industry, private donors as well as government.
•	UTD has managed to hire good faculty (equivalent to a higher ranked university) and is continuing to attract top researchers/professors.  
•	Rapid infrastructure development
•	Funding/Scholarship opportunities for students are better than similarly ranked university.
cons:
•	Although there has been increase in number of courses offered as well as improvement in quality of classes, UTD still needs improve on class room teaching. Some classes are excellent, however some are not useful at all. 

•	Research groups are small since this is a young university. This forces students to perform individual research (or in small group) rather than being a part of big group. Thus, number of publications per PhD/MS student are lower than top school.

job_title: Administrative Assistant I in Richardson, TX
pros: If you know the right people you can advance, or move to a new position on campus.
cons:
You really need to know the right people on campus to go anywhere.
Most of upper management bases their decisions on personal feelings and not necessarily the most qualified person.
No Maternity leave, just short term disability.

review_title: Some departments/areas of the University are great to work for...others are not.
pros: Beautiful campus, great campus resources such as on campus activity center and dining options, growing campus, excellent benefits starting on hire date, lots of vacation and sick leave
cons: Some departments are very disorganized and dysfunctional. While the campus is growing steadily, staff hiring has not kept up with the growth, neither have operating budgets for many departments.

review_title: UT Austin is not too hard, but not too satisfying.
pros: There is great diversity in the community. A lot of different people work in IT across the campus and provide a flexible environment to find somewhere that you're comfortable. State regulation means that you cannot be forced to work overtime. Requirements are relatively low; there is a lot of patience for less than top notch work. The community is very supportive of self-education, although it is rarely acted on by most individuals. There is a strong network of public transportation and activities as a result of being at the University. The economy and local business is vibrant and eclectic because of the younger population and general Austinite culture.
cons: Competence does not seem highly valued. Either it isn't seen as a primary prerequisite, management doesn't recognize it, or management doesn't want to act on it. Everyone seems happy to keep doing the same thing every day. There is a lot of focus on maintaining the status quo, and very little emphasis on making things better. There is no emphasis on metrics for measuring improvement (especially without things like profit/revenue streams to worry about). There is no clear mission or goal, most work is reactive to pressing problems or state mandates. Systemic inability to take responsibility for mistakes is common; much of the central IT community refuses to acknowledge problems growing under their noses. I personally am afraid that the entire operation is asking to be outsourced because everyone is so busy being petty; even the few of us who care and work to make it better might get tossed out with the rest.

review_title: Good and warm environment with decent people
pros: I would say it is a good and stable job to work in a friendly environment. You also have chance to develop your career in here if you enjoy in an academic system.
cons: connection with industry leading professional is a bit loose. More events should be hosted  to invited people working in the industries to create connections between graduates and companies.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Working for UT as a graduate research assistant provides a great opportunity to be involved with cutting edge research.  The research programs at UT have significant funding compared to other universities.
cons: The downsides of working at UT are minimal.  Being a state university the pay is standard with other government jobs.

review_title: Old building and equipment for a dental school
pros: Professors are about as helpful as any other school i am familiar with. The cost for UT schools is much lower than most others nationwide.
cons: The building and bays are really old. The administration has stopped investing in the infrastructure of the current school to save money for a new school in the future.

review_title: Great position for those interested in a career in the health field.
pros: Extremely flexible with work schedule and dress.  Understands importance of family.  Good medical insurance coverage.  Senior executive leadership is excellent though competence of some middle management is questionable.  Fairly easy to change positions/divisons/centers.  Environment is cozy.
cons: Slow-paced (may be a pro for some).  Not very innovative, slow to change.  Too theoretical, definitely not enough practical application of research and not enough emphasis on prevention.

review_title: Could be a great place to work.
pros: It is a large institution that is doing great work in education and research.
cons: It is an organization that is mid-management heavy. Front line employees have little to no support if or when there is a problem or issue with a supervisor. The institutions sides with the supervisor more often than not.

review_title: Learning Center is a great place to learn.
job_title: Learning Center Tutor in Austin, TX
pros:
Flexible working hours
Interactive with students frequently
Enhance teaching and learning experience
cons: Close to none.  Lazy students are hard to work with sometimes since they want to know the answers for their homework which is due in 30 minutes rather than understanding the materials.

pros: Great work/life balance.  Never worked a minute after 5:00pm.
cons: Worst job i've ever had!  This place is a breeding ground for mediocrity.  If you're poor at your job, you should work here.  You'll never get fired and management is fine with the mediocrity.

job_title: Degree Plan Evaluator in Richardson, TX
pros: They are extremely flexible and work with you especially if you are having personal issues. It seems like they really have your best interest at heart.
cons: There are not that many opportunities for advancement, especially within the offices. People tend to work here for a long time so its hard to advance.

pros: Excellent resources and facilities with competitive faculty. Laid back atmosphere to keep things less intense than other universities.  Good place to settle in and accomplish scientific goals.
cons: Parking, parking, parking! Must park 6 blocks from campus every morning. Too many undergrads and students everywhere. A little too laid back sometimes, people not always ambitious.

pros: Its a happening place, the work culture is really nice and professional and they pay you good. The management is very nice.
cons: The growth options are good but limited. Besides they isn't much of industry exposure for a profession like mine, that is engineering

pros: - The pay and the benefits were quite decent, however other negative things outweigh that easily.
cool work environment, reasonable package and low cost of living. Also, highly cooperative university policies make it a great place to work.
cons: low pay, high work load, low career growth rate and lack of exposure to the industry and the probability of getting stuck is high.

pros: There are some very competent people working here but in general these people are not in leadership roles.
cons: There is a lot money wasted by this organization for unnecessary high level employee 'perks' that is really sad considering we are cutting staff at lower levels.

review_title: Relaxed environment but you'll have to put up with quite a few incompetent staff members.
pros: Very casual.  Relaxed with your work schedule.  Friendly and youthful demographic
cons: Lots of older staff who refuse to learn new technology and hinder the growth of the departments

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Richardson, TX
pros: GOOD ACADEMIC ENVIRONMENT. Since it is academics, you can work on your own schedule. The requirements to PhD graduation are quite flexible.
cons: NO CAREER GUIDANCE FOR SCIENCES. CAREER CENTER IS GOOD ONLY FOR ENGINEERING. Salary is not that great, but that is true for all PhDs.

pros: Its the biggest employer in the city of Austin, which is an amazing city to live in.  The weather is great
cons: You are on a college campus in the middle of downtown Austin which can be quite noisy.  And there is alot of orange

pros: Good benefits, nice building, location
cons: It depends on the department. It could be great, but there are many toxic work environments in the system offices. Ask around if you are considering role in a specific one.  At External Relations there is a very toxic atmosphere and office politics. No respect. You are better off not playing the game, but  is nonetheless draining and soul crushing.  Approximately half of the department has left, which tells you a lot. Talk to any current or former employee of the office. Shrinking department and no room for growth.

pros: Top-notch science, possibility to interact with researchers from the whole texas medical center, great libraries, a chance to venture into industry.
cons: high-paced environment does not leave too much time for a personal life and administrative staff is often not quite supportive.

pros: BEG is one of the most famous institutes in oil and gas studies in the world. It has kept a very good reputation in the field.
cons: It's a soft-money research center and some time most of the employees have pressure to find and maintain the funds. Some of the employees work vvery hard there, especially during weekends. They need to spend more time with their families.

review_title: An alphabet soup. Hope you like your department!
pros: Generally great coworkers. Downtown location is fantastic. Departmental directors for the most part are very good at what they do.
cons: Few opportunities for advancement. Vulnerable to the state's budget. Inflexible attitude towards new technology. Lack of mentorship culture, instead focuses on leader development classes and the like.

review_title: UT Neurobiology and Animal Resource Center
job_title: Research Scientist Associate in Austin, TX
pros: Employee benefits are fantastic, campus is gorgeous, wonderful central location, employee discounts throughout Austin
cons: No employee raises for last 2 years (except for Mack Brown receiving $5 million plus bonuses) despite football team raising over 150 million dollars this last season.

review_title: If you're going to work at a University, Texas is a great place to do it.
pros: Intellectual freedom, personal flexibility, laid back lifestyle.  Austin is a fantastic place to live and has a reasonable cost of living.
cons: University pay, limited opportunity for promotion

pros:
Very friendly co-workers
Laid-back environment
Less stressful, less peer pressure
Center of happenings at Austin and reasonable compensation with good benefits
cons:
May not get satisfactory recognition of your good work. Hard to excel in this big school with ~30000 employes.
Salary is lower than many other schools

pros: You receive so many transferrable skills and great benefits.
cons: They are starting to cut back on the benefits that they give in order to increase their profit. RA's no longer have their own rooms! Change is so slow!

review_title: Great work life balance, and friendly place for parents to work.
pros: UT System Office of General Counsel was a great place to work, with low stress, very manageable hours, and a super friendly work environment.
cons: As part of the trade off for not having to work that much, you also don't get paid as much if you were with a firm.

review_title: It's a good career if you want stability in your life.
pros: Stability, good benefits, nice people, many job categories. Work from home and car pooling is encouraged, free mass transit in Austin.
cons: Little advancement /career path encouragement. Entitled career personnel. Must not mind lower salary than some private industries. State politics gets in the way.

review_title: Learned a lot of valuable lessons working for the UT system
job_title: Student Affairs Chair in Richardson, TX
pros: Great people that provided helpful mentoring and advice.  Work life balance was great for being a full-time student and working.
cons: The pay was low, but I was grateful for the compensation.

review_title: Not a good place for young faculty
pros: The benefit is OK. The UT Direct system is convenient and friendly. I can still use it even I left for a year. That is good so I can still get my information updated and get my W2.
cons: The school management don't care the development of the young faculty. The pay is low. There is not much raise.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Top notch chemistry department. Last time I checked it was hovering around 10th in the nation. Great respectable name. Austin is a great place to live and work.
cons: Not that many cons but obviously your are going to be working on a university salary so you better love the research you do and enjoy the other perks

job_title: Senior Construction Inspector in Houston, TX
pros: Great hours and working conditions, and benefits. Each team member is respected for their contribution, and is provided an amount of autonomy.
cons: Work days follow university class schedule when active projects do not demand your time. Have to work some weekends, holidays, and after hour shifts.

pros: very family-oriented, no one blinks an eye when you need to take time off
cons: a bit boring and outdated.  I feel more like a secretary in the 50s than an assistant.  But I guess that depends on management

pros: Great benefits such as almost 2 weeks off for Christmas, great retirement plan
cons: Difficult to collaborate with other department, usually it took several weeks to solve one minor problem. Everything is always delayed. Too many rules and procedure, however they are not efficiency

Small campus (although expanding fast) vs High student intake results in crowded buildings, classes and lack of sufficient on-campus housing

Area around university isn't very good

pros: A very stable and friendly university enviorment to work with. People in human resource are kind and helpful. Cafeteria is good, several choices.
cons: Currently there are a lot of constructions going on now. Promotion is not easy, manager doesn't always recognize your efforts.

review_title: Good place to learn, to live and to contribute

review_title: UT System is a great place to work.

review_title: a good place for graduate school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: As a graduate student and research assistant, I received BCBS health insurance and access to the University of Texas academic, research, and recreational facilities.

pros: good benefits, nice people, great opportunities, good pay, relaxed environment, upcoming university, plenty of funding, great location, good for all fields - research oriented or not
